channel.title: International Programs - E Pakag
channel.description: e-Pak Ag - helping farmers through the use of Information Communication Technology (ICT).

item.title: Cattle
item.description:
About Cattle in Afghanistan

  • Afghanistan National Livestock Census 2006 Report (11 MB) (FAO)
  • Status Genetic Resources Report (1.4 MB) (FAO)

Pasture and Fodder

  • Animals graze pastures in spring and summer, and are fed in the home compound during the lean feed periods of winter and early spring.
  • Challenges to Grazing Land Info Sheet (UC Davis and SIU)
  • Fodder
    • Crop Options Fact Sheet (UC Davis, SIU and U Georgia)
    • Tree Options Info Sheet (UC Davis from FAO)
    • Alfalfa Role and Establishment Report (1.9 MB) (FAF Developments)
    • Pasture/Forage Resources Profile Report (FAO)

Cattle General

  • Handling Cattle
    • Approaching and Handling Fact Sheet (SIU and UC Davis) Manual (Texas A&M University)
    • Humans and Brucellosis Fact Sheet (UC Davis)
    • Moving Around and Approaching a Herd of Cattle icon video Video (UC Davis)

Dairy

  • Dairy Industry Revitalization Project Case Study (USAID)
  • Production and Processing in Afghanistan Case Study (1.7 MB) (MAIL)
  • Milk Quality Control Manual (ICARDA)
  • Milk Processing Technologies for Small-Scale Producers Manual (1.6 MB) (ICARDA)

Beef

  • Care Practices Manual (UCD)

Diseases

  • Always be cautious around sick animals as some diseases can be spread to humans by touching.
  • Diagnostics: Disease or Poor Nutrition? Fact Sheet (SIU with UC Davis)
  • Disease Prevention (Biosecurity)
    • Limiting Disease Spread Fact Sheet (SIU with UC Davis)
    • From the Illustrated Manual of Infectious Diseases of Livestock In Afghanistan (Fort Valley State University):
      • Cleaning and Disinfecting Fact Sheet English, (Dari) دری, and پشتو (Pashto)
      • Carcass Disposal Fact Sheet English, (Dari) دری, and پشتو (Pashto)
  • Specific diseases
    • Anthrax Fact Sheet (DCA)
    • Brucellosis and Other Diseases Causing Abortions Fact Sheet (Fort Valley State University)
    • Clostridial Diseases Fact Sheet English, (Dari) دری, and پشتو (Pashto) (Fort Valley State University)
    • Echinococcosis Fact Sheet English, (Dari) دری, and پشتو (Pashto) (Fort Valley State University)
    • Foot and Mouth Disease Fact Sheet (DCA)
    • Johne's Disease Fact Sheet (SIU and UC Davis)
    • Rabies Fact Sheet (DCA)

item.title: Wheat
item.description:
Production

  • General Wheat Production پشتو (Pashto) (IRD)
  • Issues and Options in Wheat Production Fact Sheet English, دری (Dari), and پشتو (Pashto) (UC Davis)
  • Food and Food Security Info Sheet (UC Davis)
  • Cropping 101 Short Manual (UC Davis)
  • Seed and Seed Systems Webpage
  • Fertilization
    • Fact Sheet (IFA)
    • Nitrogen Requirements of Annual Crops Fact Sheet (UC Davis)
  • Wheat Growth Stages (Feekes scale) Fact Sheet English and پشتو (Pashto) (RONNA)
  • Planting and Harvesting Dates
  • Wheat Planting icon video Videos Afghanistan and USA
  • Wheat Doctor (CIMMYT on-line diagnostic tool)
  • Water Management
    • Field Observations for Irrigation Scheduling Fact Sheet (UC Davis)
    • Too Much or Too Little? Fact Sheet (UC Davis)

Production Maps by Province

Total Wheat Production

  • Production by Province Interactive Map (UC Davis)
  • Cultivated Area by Province Interactive Map (UC Davis)
  • Total area Wheat Yield Comparison 2010-2011 PDF Map (1.46 MB) (iMMAP)

Irrigated Wheat Production

  • Production by Province Interactive Map (UC Davis)
  • Cultivated Area by ProvinceInteractive Map (UC Davis)
  • Yield and Production Comparison 2010-2011 PDF Map (1.24 MB) (iMMAP)

Rainfed Wheat Production

  • Production by Province Interactive Map (UC Davis)
  • Cultivated Area by Province Interactive Map (UC Davis)
  • Yield and Production Comparison 2010-2011 PDF Map (1.24 MB) (iMMAP)

Pest Management

Disease

  • UG 99 is a new (potentially devastating) race of the disease stem rust. UG 99-resistant wheat varieties have been developed. Contact CIMMYT or FAO.

Insects

Moroccan Locust

Factsheet

For more information see FAO and Plantwise

Sunn Pest

Brochure

(ICARDA)

Postharvest

  • Dry seed to less than 14% moisture and clean, then use the IRRI Superbag Fact sheet (IRRI) or PIC bag icon videoVideo (Purdue)

item.title: Rice
item.description:
Production

  • Cropping 101 Short Manual (UC Davis)
  • Seed and Seed Systems Webpage
  • Fertilization
  • Cropping 101 Short Manual (UC Davis)
    • Manual (IFA)
    • Nitrogen Requirements of Annual Crops Fact Sheet (UC Davis)
  • Production by Province Interactive Map (UC Davis)
  • Cultivated Area by ProvinceInteractive Map (UC Davis)
  • See Rice Knowledge Bank (IRRI on-line tool)

Pest Management

  • Rice has a number of pest problems including small aquatic animals, armyworms, grasshoppers, molds, rots and blight. Crop rotations, pesticides, flooding the fields, and planting resistant varieties can help to reduce these problems.
  • Rice Doctor (IRRI on-line diagnostic tool)

Postharvest

  • Dry seed to less than 14% moisture and clean, then use the IRRI Superbag Fact sheet (IRRI) or PIC bag icon videoVideo (Purdue)
  • Rice Knowledge Bank (IRRI on-line tool)

item.title: Other Field Crops
item.description:
• Hing
  • Pigeon Pea
  • Soybean
  • Sunn Hemp

Hing

Asafoetida, or hing, is a perennial herb (genus Ferula) growing wild in the deserts of Afghanistan's northern provinces. The stem and roots of the Hing plant emit sap that is dried and used as a spice. Currently Hing is collected and sold informally in local markets.

Priority problems for hing include lack of domesticated varieties.

Priority opportunities for hing are agricultural intensification, including investment in crop establishment, cultivar research, and extension services for farmers.

Improved Agricultural Techniques and Natural Resource Management Course Module: Hing Manual Dari (1.2 MB) (People in Need)

Pigeon Pea

Pigeon pea (and sunn hemp) - while not major crops - are grown around the country for use as windbreaks and/or as a living fence to help prevent animals moving between fields. It is also recognized as a drought-tolerant green manure, provides weed control, and is used as firewood in tandoor ovens.

Pigeon Pea, known as harhar (Pashto), is most commonly found in the eastern provinces (Nangharhar, Laghman, Kunar, etc.) and northern (Balkh, Kunduz, Tahar) provinces.

Priority problems include lack of recognition of its nutritional value for humans and livestock.

Priority opportunities include increased awareness of nutritional value and greater awareness in other parts of the country of its benefits as a windbreak, living fence, green manure source, and weed control mechanism.

These draft problems and opportunities are based on feedback from Najmudin Rohid (AAEP Kabul).

  • Overview Info Sheet (UC Davis)
  • Seed and Seed Systems Webpage
  • Pigeon Pea Production Manual (Tropical Forages)
  • Pigeon Pea Nutritional Benefits Info Sheet (UC Davis)

Soybean

Soybean has not been traditionally grown in Afghanistan, but has become increasingly popular since 2010 as a result of major pushes from foreign NGOs and grower's associations, which have worked to create export markets and supply necessary inputs. Sustained access to necessary inputs, particularly machinery, is currently the major limitation for soybean production in Afghanistan. Soybean is a healthy, low-cost, and easily preserved source of protein, making it a good alternative to meats in diversifying family diets.

Priority problems and opportunities for soybean are not yet confirmed.

  • Best Management Practices for Soybean Production in South Dakota (northern USA) Manual (iGrow Soybeans)
  • Soybean Production Manual English (excerpt) and Dari (3.3 MB) (NEI Foundation)

Sunn Hemp

Sunn Hemp (and pigeon pea) - while not major crops - are grown around the country for use as windbreaks and/or as a living fence to help prevent animals moving between fields. Sunn Hemp is also used for green manure, as well as fodder for goats and camels. Its bitter flavor deters most other livestock. It grows in warm climates (eastern provinces, such as Nangharhar) and is a good source of oil.

Priority problems for sunn hemp are not yet confirmed.

Priority opportunities include increased awareness of sunn hemp as an oil source.

These draft priority problems are based on feedback from Najmudin Rohid (AAEP Kabul).

  • Overview Info Sheet (UCD)
  • Production Summary and Manual (U Hawaii)
